document.docAuthor: Li, Zhao-Hui, Chen, Jian-Xiu & Li, Jing
document.docTitle: Papirioides zhejiangensis Li, Chen & Li, 2007, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of the genus Papirioides (Collembola: Dicyrtomidae) from China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of the genus Papirioides (Collembola: Dicyrtomidae) from China

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype : female (mounted on slide), China : Zhejiang Province: Wenzhou: Wuyanling National Nature Reserve, deciduous forest, under wet wood and in litter
4 .viii. 2005
, collection number C 9280 , coll. CHEN Jian-xiu, YAN Hai-juan, ZHANG Feng & JI Ming. Paratypes :
3 females
and
1 male
, same data as holotype ;
32 specimens
in alcohol. All deposited in the School of Life Science, Nanjing University.
Description. Body length: up to 2.3 mm.

Color pattern. Ground color yellow. Color pattern basically symmetric. Distal 2 / 3 of cephalic dorsum brown, basal 1 / 3 pale yellow with 2 brown bands lateral to each eye patche. Head ventrally brown except basal part yellow. Eye patches small and dark purple.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Papirioides zhejiangensis
sp. nov.
: habitus, dorsal view.

FIGURE 2.
Papirioides zhejiangensis
sp. nov.
: habitus, lateral view.

FIGURE 3 .
Papirioides zhejiangensis
sp. nov.
: habitus, ventral view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Ant. I purple, Ant. II pale yellow with median and distal purple bands, Ant. III purple totally, Ant. IV pale yellow and distally purple.
Coxa, trochanter and femur dorsally yellow with irregular purple patches, ventrally pale purple; tibiotarsus dark purple with 3 transverse yellow bands.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 4–11 .
Papirioides zhejiangensis
sp. nov.
: 4, left eye-patch; 4, cephalic chaetotaxy; 6, labrum; 7, ant. I; 8, ant. II; 9, ant. III subapical organ; 10, dorsum of great abdomen; 11, dorsal club.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Head. Eyes 8 + 8 , ocelli A, B, E, F & H large; C, D & G small. Dorsal cephalic chaetotaxy after Bretfeld ( 1999 ) and shown in
Figs 4 & 5
. Eyepatch with 2 setae, seta 1 spiny and larger than seta 2 , seta 2 setaceous. Head apex with 2 + 2 spines, ap 2 much larger than ap 1 . Dorsal head-back with 3 + 3 spiny setae, setae in pairs 1 & 3 larger. Frons with 2 + 2 longitudinal rows of setae, 5 & 3 spiny setae respectively present in rows a & b; a 4 much larger than others. Clypeus with 1, 1 , 2, 1 , 1, 1 subequal spiny setae. Lower frons with 8 + 8 cup sensilla, 1 + 1 oval organs on ventral-lateral parts, and 7 + 7 transversal rows (a–g) of common setae. Labral setae as 6 / 7, 3 , 4 (
Fig. 6
). Length ratio of antenna to head as 2.3–2.6: 1 in female and 3.2: 1 in male. Antennal segment ratio as I: II: III: IV = 1 –1.27: 7.27–7.82: 7.27–7.64: 1.18–1.27. Ant. I with 1 ventral and 6 dorsal setae, ventral one much smaller (
Fig. 7
). Ant. II with 20 setae, 1 ventral and 2 dorsal cup sensilla (
Fig. 8
). Ant. III with 2, 4 , 4 cup sensilla respectively at basal, middle and distal parts, basal 2 thick. Distal part of Ant.
III 8
- subsegmented, each subsegment having 4–7 setae arranged in whorl. Ant III subapical organ with 2 fingerlike sensilla lying in shallow depression (
Fig. 9
). Ant.
IV 7
-subsegmented.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12–24.
Papirioides zhejiangensis
sp. nov.
: 12, coxa, foreleg; 13, trochanter, foreleg; 14, femur, foreleg; 15, tibiotarsus, foreleg; 16, coxa, midleg; 17, trochanter, midleg; 18, femur, midleg; 19, tibiotarsus, midleg; 20, coxa, hindleg; 21, trochanter, hindleg; 22, femur, hindleg; 23, tibiotarsus with one posterior seta enlarged, hindleg; 24, pretarsus, hindleg.

FIGURES 25–31 .
Papirioides zhejiangensis
sp. nov.
: 25, ventral tube; 26, retinaculum; 27, manubrium; 28, anterior setae of dens; 29, posterior setae of dens; 30, mucro; 31, female anogenital segment with several specialized setae enlarged, dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Small abdomen. Chaetotaxy after Bretfeld ( 1999 ) and
Yosii ( 1969 , in brackets)
. Dorsal region with setae m 1 (M), A 3 (M), DL 2 (N), P 1 (H) & a0 as strong spines; a 1–3 large and serrate; sa ciliate and sa serrate; A 1 & A 2 as cup sensilla; P0 (G’) short and thin, P 3 (S) as sensillum and not directly anterior to circumanal setae, P 1 ’ (T) straight and thin; DL 1 and P 2 (G) absent. Ventral region with seta VL 2 (L) as strong spine; av 1–4 serrate, av 1 & av 2 stronger than av 3 & av 4 ; appendices anales av 5 as thick spines and shorter than av 1–4 ; sa 1–3 ciliate, sa 3 much larger than sa 1 & sa 2 ; AV 1 as cup sensilla, AV 2–8 small and smooth; cuticular cone near and internal to AV 2 (
Fig. 31
).
Ecology. Found under wet wood and in litter in deciduous forest.
Etymology. Named after the type locality, Zhejiang Province, China .

Discussion. The new species,
Papirioides zhejiangensis
, is most close to the Indonesian species
P. tonsori
in the circumanal and dens setae. However, it differs from the latter in the facial setal pattern, length of dorsal club on the great abdomen, and number of short spines on the club. It is very similar to another Indonesian species
P. jacobsoni
in the color pattern. However, it is readily distinguished from the latter by the facial setal pattern, length of dorsal club on the great abdomen, circumanal setae and other features. The comparison of the new species with the three species in the genus with dorsal club on the great abdomen is shown in the following table. The Japanese species
P. uenoi
is excluded from the table since it was poorly described. However, the new species is also easily separated from it by the absence of two dorsal brown stripes on great abdomen and the dens with setae mostly serrate rather than smooth or weakly serrate as in the latter.

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. Comparison of species with dorsal club in the genus Papirioides.

tr.th: Circumanal setae P1on small abdomen Dens setae E1 / E2 Ant. III subsegments
Mucro outer teeth Mucro inner teeth

subSubSection.paragraph: The present study was supported by a grant from National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 30370175 ). Special thanks are offered to Dr. G. Bretfeld, University of Kiel, Germany and Dr. P. Greenslade, Division of Entomology, CSIRO , Canberra, Australia , for their constructive suggestions and kindness to offer references. Thanks are also given to the Bureau of Wuyanling National Nature Reserve for its support to our collecting.
